Boys appear like hostile Indians -- behind them, to the side of them, in front of them -- silently escorting them under the pier. direction.raw_text: It's Denton's story. 'The Dark Truth: Why Our City Really Fears the Newsie Strike, by Bryan Denton. Last night I saw naked force exercised against mere boys, the Newsies, who earn at best a few pennies a day. I wondered why so much, against so little -- ' David refuses to listen; he angrily steps out on the fire escape and stares off into the city. Sarah keeps reading to herself. direction.raw_text: Yeah, run, Davey! We got the best parta ya family right here! David, furious, runs down the sidewalk towards them. Morris slips on some brass knuckles in anticipation. Sarah struggles, screaming -- SARAH David, no -- don't -- ! Oscar hangs on to Sarah, enjoying himself -- suddenly, from behind, two hands grab the rim of his derby and jerk it down to the bridge of his nose. Blinded, he releases Sarah and staggers around, trying to pry the hat off his eyes. Les looks up to see -- LES Jack! Jack flashes him a grin        as he works on Morris's bread basket. Just as Oscar         frees himself from the derby, David leaps on him like        a fury. Punches fly and the Delanceys beat a quick        retreat down the sidewalk, yelling back -- MORRIS Ya better run, cowboy -- we're tellin' Weasel! You'll be back in the Refuge by supper time!

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, run, ya lousy coward -- run!

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong. You touched people you don't even know about.

dialogue.raw_text: Denton looked out for hisself just like I gotta do -- so save it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just listen! 'The men who run this city are terrified of the Newsies strike -- because other child laborers in the factories and sweatshops are hearing the message of the Newsies leader --' LES That's you!   He's writin' about you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'In the voice of Jack Kelly, these children hear strength and pride. Most of all, they hear hope...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that is what terrifies the powers-that-be, for they know our city thrives on the shame of child labor. Therefore, Jack Kelly's voice must be stopped, whatever the cost... (stops) Damn good writing, isn't it? (CONTINUED) )R(    5/8/91 - PINK (2)                                   99. 160D   CONTINUED:

dialogue.raw_text: The minute I show my face, I'm back in the Refuge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'd have help this time. I've been investigating the Refuge -- I know somebody who's going to be very interested in Snyder's little racket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (wryly) What happened to the ace war correspondent?

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever happens, it's Jack's decision. He's the one in danger.

dialogue.raw_text: (picks it up) ... Another rally, right under Pulitzer's nose, and not just the Newsies -- JACK -- Every workin' kid from every sweatshop in New York. We gotta get the word out -- let's go get the Newsies -- (catches himself) They still think I'm a scab...

dialogue.raw_text: How're you gonna reach all these people? No paper in New York will print anything about the strike.

dialogue.raw_text: We're Newsies, ain't we?   So we make our own paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Be quiet and let me think.

dialogue.raw_text: Whattaya need to start a paper? Writers, right? So we got Denton. What else?

dialogue.raw_text: Advertisements! (as they look at him) Cartoons?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (the cold facts) A printing press. And no paper or printer is going to defy Pulitzer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Les. Go set me straight with the Newsies, okay? Tell 'em to meet us later at the World Building.
